text: Dan Simons and I were teaching a course
at Harvard University on research
methods in the psychology department
this is a course where students have to
design their own psychology research
projects and carry them out and as part
of the course we also thought it would
be a good idea to have some group
projects that everyone could participate
in Dan had the idea to uh look at some
work that had been done in the 1970s a
somewhat famous experiment by R niser
one of the pioneers of cognitive
pschology who had some people sort of
play basketball passing balls around on
an empty basketball court and managed to
get the groups of people to overlap by
filming the with special mirrors and
then while people are watching these
basketball players they're supposed to
count the number of times the ball gets
passed about halfway through the video a
woman carrying an umbrella walks through
the basketball court the surprising
finding of his experiment was that many
people who were counting the basketball
passes didn't see the woman with the
walking through and didn't remember her
being there at all the funny thing about
the experiment though was that since it
was filmed using the special technique
with mirrors everyone was sort of
invisible and transparent and you could
see through them it was a very unusual
looking display it's the kind of thing
that nowadays you would do with digital
video editing back in the 1970s he used
mirrors some people had sort of
dismissed the finding that people missed
this very obvious and Salient thing like
a woman walking through a basketball
game because it was a strange looking
visual display so we decided to try to
do a new version of this experim
experiment where all the action was live
and we had six people passing
basketballs around sort of choreographed
to not run into each other and to not
throw the ball in each other's face and
so on and that was a bit of a challenge
in setting up this experiment but that's
what we have students in the course for
we managed to get it right and then we
had a woman walk through carrying an
umbrella just like ncer did uh what was
uh a little more amusing for us though
was that one of the other professors in
the department happened to have a
gorilla suit lying around in his lab and
we thought it would be fun to have
someone walk through wearing the gorilla
suit and see whether that was noticed
and we at first thought that people
would notice the gorilla walking through
the basketball game because there's no
longer this sort of transparent
see-through display uh and the gorilla
actually stayed on the screen for nine
full seconds in one of the versions of
our video but when we ran the experiment
and our students went out and tested
people on the Harvard campus we found
that about half of the people did not at
all notice the gorilla and in fact we're
very surprised they had notied the
gorilla there were actually sort of two
findings from this experiment one you
can miss very Salient things like a
gorilla walking right in front of you
and two that you're shocked that you
could miss it most people seem to have
the intuitive idea that they're going to
see this kind of thing and they're
really surprised when they find out that
they
don't what this experiment shows is that
when we're paying attention to something
basically doing a task that demands our
attention such as counting the passes of
the basketball in this case or really
any other kind of really attention
demanding task that we do we can uh
seriously overestimate our ability to do
other tasks at the same time and
especially to to notice and handle
unexpected or surprising things we think
that we're going to notice unexpected
things that come into our field of view
and we think we're going to pay
attention to the things we should pay
attention to but in fact when we're
focused on one task we're noticing and
paying attention to a lot less than we
really
think this experiment implies a lot
about our behavior in everyday life for
example um when we are driving and
talking on a cell phone at the same time
we get the feeling that we're actually
driving just as well as when we're not
talking on the phone that's part of why
we do things like talking on the phone
while we're driving or even send text
messages or read our email which are
actually much worse but even talking on
the phone while driving depletes a lot
of your attention talking on the phone
while you're driving is like counting
the basketball passes in our experiment
you can still drive but what you're
going to have a problem with is noticing
unexpected things and when you think
about it those are the really important
things to notice when you're driving
it's one thing to just drive down and
open Highway at night it's another thing
to drive um in the suburbs when someone
might be pulling out of their driveway
right in front of you or someone might
be stopping short right in front of you
and you want to have the reaction time
to be able to stop and not crash into
them or even worse someone pushes a baby
stroller out in front of the uh in front
of the road um so we're actually a lot
worse at that than we think we are and
we should in fact put down the cell
phone while we're driving uh and perhaps
even zip it up in a briefcase or a purse
or something like that um those are some
of the implications for everyday life
but it's not just driving there are many
other situations like this um for
example the security screeners at
airports um we sort of have the
impression that they're paying attention
to everything that's in our suitcase and
our luggage and so on um but actually
everybody has sort of an inflated
impression of how much they're paying
attention to and we may not be as safe
as we think we are even with you know
trained and dedicated people doing that
um lifeguards at swimming pools uh
Radiologists looking at Medical scans
for anomalies and so on um when you're
looking for one thing or paying
attention to one thing it's easy to not
notice other things and to not realize
that you're not noticing those
things a TV news magazine that covered
our research actually recreated the
experiment for themselves in their own
Studios and they had a bunch of
volunteers come in and look at the
videotape and and count the passes and
and miss the gorilla and they filmed the
reactions of some of them and my
favorite one of all was someone who said
that bear didn't go through there did it
did you notice that what I'm wearing
actually changed several times during
the course of this interview some people
might have noticed some of the changes
but it's probably unusual to notice all
of those changes
